Award.AwardTitle: Genomic Architecture of Maize Ethylene Response During Germination
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF National Plant Genome Initiative Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2017. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow who also presents a plan to broaden participation in biology. The host institution for the fellowship is the Cornell University and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Michael Scanlon.

One approach to promote food security in a fluctuating climate is to identify and develop climate-resilient crops. Maize is an indispensable food source and industrial feedstock for much of the world. Maize is susceptible to stress, such as heat, drought and flooding. Ethylene is a key regulator of plant growth, development and stress response; however, neither the genetic control of ethylene growth response nor its natural variation are understood in maize. Knowledge of the genetic architecture of ethylene response will enable future engineering efforts on ethylene-mediated stress tolerance in the cereals. Broader impacts include the formation of interactive programs to increase public genetic and genomic literacy. The Fellow will teach core concepts in genetics and genomics to participants outside of STEM fields. Participants, in turn, will interpret this into public art that communicates genetic principles. Training objectives for the Fellow include gaining proficiency in plant genomics, association mapping and bioinformatics.

This research will evaluate the genomic architecture of ethylene growth response in maize. The ethylene response is an important target for crop adaptation to climate. The Fellow will conduct genome wide association studies to investigate the allelic architecture of maize ethylene response, and will identify transcriptomic networks and chromatin signatures associated with ethylene treatment. The proposed research has significant potential to discover key alleles and genomic regions in maize that underlie stress tolerance associated with ethylene. This work will provide a foundation for future investigations on the underlying mechanisms of ethylene response in maize and in other economically vital cereals. Research outcomes will be shared with the public and research community through conferences, in publications and by submissions to data repositories: phenotypic data to Panzea (http://www.panzea.org), raw sequence data to NCBI-SRA (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sra), and gene expression data to NCBI-GEO (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo), Maize Genetics and Genomics Database (http://www.maizegdb.org), and qTeller (http://qteller.com).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The plant hormone ethylene is involved in diverse aspects of plant development and growth. Ethylene also plays a critical role in plant response to abiotic stress. Despite its importance, how ethylene mediates numerous developmental and physiological processes remains poorly resolved. The genetic basis of ethylene biosynthesis, perception and signaling derives heavily from studies in the non-crop model plant, Arabidopsis thaliana. The degree to which ethylene response is shared between Arabidopsis and monocot crop species, such as maize, remains unclear. For these reasons, understanding the genetic control of ethylene response, its genomics, and the natural variation that may underlie it will provide fundamental tools and resources for a more efficient coordination of plant development and growth, along with mitigation of stress response in diverse environments.

This project utilized functional genetics, single-cell genomics and maize diversity to provide knowledge of ethylene's role in regulating development and growth in maize. Through phenotypic analysis of the effects of mutations in ethylene signaling genes, it was found that ethylene signaling in maize is crucial for proper shoot growth and development, and ethylene signaling mutant plants are altered in their response to the hormone. Finally, significant natural variation in maize diversity lines to the hormone was observed during germination. Single-cell transcriptomics were utilized to study the ethylene pathway at high celluar resolution and genomic level. This work uncovered thousands of gene transcripts that uniquely or differentially accumulate in growing tissues. Collectively, these findings in maize provide new insights into our knowledge of ethylene action and establishes fertile grounds for future research in maize to understand more completely the effects of hormones on crop development and growth.

 

A major goal of this project was to establish an interactive program to broaden the public's basic knowledge of principle concepts in genetics and genomics. This public outreach was successful in expanding the diversity of participants by reaching outside of STEM fields to engage studio artists. In a collaboration with an artist, color-field paintings of allele segregation in maize were generated and installed at a coffee shop/gallery space and were part of a gallery walk. In a separate collaboration with an artist, a population geneticist, and a computational biologist, an juried genome-inspired light installation called ATGC was designed, constructed and exhibited. This work was displayed in a public space and reached a broad public audience. In addition to these efforts, the PI Strable trained and mentored an undergraduate student, who contributed research in this project, and who has since continued in plant science as a graduate student.
